The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a comprehensive geriatric assessment and to involve a geriatrician, or other specialist trained in geriatric care, in the patient's management.

The patient's vague symptoms of weakness, lethargy, and poor eye contact, along with the presence of healing bruises on her upper extremities, suggest a possible diagnosis of elder abuse or neglect. Geriatric patients are at higher risk for abuse and neglect, especially those who are socially isolated or living with a caregiver. A comprehensive geriatric assessment would help identify the underlying causes of the patient's symptoms, including any potential social and environmental factors that may be contributing to her vulnerability.

The assessment would involve evaluating the patient's functional status, including her ability to perform activities of daily living, her cognition, and her mood. The assessment would also include a review of her medications, her social support network, her living situation, and her access to healthcare. The geriatrician would also evaluate the patient's risk for falls, and would assess for any signs of abuse or neglect. Based on the results of the assessment, an appropriate care plan can be developed for the patient, which may include interventions such as a referral to a home health care agency, placement in a long-term care facility, or legal action if the patient is found to be a victim of elder abuse.

A 23-year-old woman presents with fever, chills, nausea, and urinary urgency and frequency. She says that her symptoms began 4 days ago and have progressively worsened. Her past medical history is significant for a 6-month history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Her vital signs include: temperature 39.0°C (102.2°F), blood pressure 100/70 mm Hg, pulse 92/min, and respiratory rate 25/min. On physical examination, there is moderate left costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
WBC 8,500/mm3
RBC 4.20 x 106/mm3
Hematocrit 41.5%
Hemoglobin 13.0 g/dL
Platelet count 225,000/mm3
Urinalysis
Color Dark yellow
Clarity Turbid
pH 6.5
Specific gravity 1.026
Glucose None
Ketones None
Nitrites Positive
Leukocyte esterase Positive
Bilirubin Negative
Urobilirubin 0.6 mg/dL
Protein Trace
Blood None
WBC 25/hpf
Bacteria Many
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by a bacterial infection. The patient's symptoms of fever, chills, nausea, and urinary urgency and frequency, along with her history of recurrent UTIs, are consistent with this diagnosis. The physical examination finding of moderate left costovertebral angle tenderness, which is a sign of pyelonephritis, a type of UTI that affects the kidneys, also supports this diagnosis.

The laboratory findings are consistent with a UTI as well, including an elevated white blood cell count (WBC 8,500/mm3) and an elevated urobilirubin (0.6 mg/dL) which is a breakdown product of bilirubin and is found in urine when there is infection or inflammation in the urinary tract. The urinalysis shows a dark yellow, turbid urine with a pH of 6.5, a specific gravity of 1.026, positive nitrites and leukocyte esterase, many bacteria, and a high number of white blood cells (25/hpf) which are consistent with a urinary tract infection.

It is also worth noting that the patient has a history of recurrent UTIs, which could indicate an underlying structural or functional abnormality in the urinary tract or an underlying condition, such as diabetes that increases the risk of recurrent UTIs. It would be appropriate to consult with a urologist or nephrologist to evaluate the underlying cause and to implement preventive measures to reduce the risk of recurrent UTIs.

A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of lower extremity swelling and frothy urine. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C infection. Physical examination shows 3+ pitting edema of the lower legs and ankles. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show evidence of liver cirrhosis. The patient's symptoms of lower extremity swelling and frothy urine, combined with his history of chronic hepatitis C infection, suggest that he may have developed cirrhosis of the liver. Cirrhosis is a chronic liver disease characterized by the replacement of normal liver tissue with scar tissue, leading to structural changes in the liver and impaired function.

The edema (swelling) in the lower legs and ankles is a common symptom of cirrhosis, as the liver's inability to properly filter and remove fluids from the body can lead to fluid accumulation in the legs and other parts of the body. The frothy urine, which is caused by the presence of protein in the urine, is also a symptom of cirrhosis, as the liver's inability to properly metabolize proteins can lead to protein leakage into the urine.

Additional tests that could be done to confirm the diagnosis of cirrhosis includes a liver function test, imaging tests like ultrasound, CT scan or MRI, and biopsy of the liver. Once cirrhosis is confirmed, management would include addressing the underlying cause of the cirrhosis, if possible and addressing the symptoms and complications of the cirrhosis such as addressing the edema, proteinuria, and preventing complications such as variceal bleeding, infections, and liver failure.

A 72-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of increased urinary frequency and a weakened urinary stream. He has a history of gout, obesity, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. He currently takes allopurinol, metformin, glyburide, and rosuvastatin. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals an enlarged, non-tender prostate without nodules or masses. An ultrasound reveals a uniformly enlarged prostate that is 40mL in size. His physician starts him on a new medication. After taking the first dose, the patient experiences lightheadedness upon standing and has a syncopal event. Which of the following mechanisms of action is most consistent with the medication in question?

The most consistent mechanism of action of the medication in question is alpha-adrenergic receptor blockers. The patient's symptoms of increased urinary frequency and weakened urinary stream, along with the finding of an enlarged prostate on examination, are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a condition in which the prostate gland becomes enlarged. The medication that the physician started the patient on is likely an alpha-adrenergic receptor blocker such as terazosin, doxazosin, or tamsulosin. These medications work by blocking the action of alpha-adrenergic receptors in the smooth muscle of the prostate and bladder neck, which results in relaxation of the smooth muscle and improvement of symptoms of BPH.

The side effect of lightheadedness upon standing and syncopal event are consistent with orthostatic hypotension, which is a common side effect of alpha-adrenergic receptor blockers, and it happens when the medication causes a decrease in blood pressure, especially when the patient stands up from a seated or lying down position. The patient should be advised to rise slowly from a seated or lying down position, and to notify the physician if symptoms persist or worsen.

A 39-year-old male presents with muscle weakness in his upper and lower extremities. The patient has also noticed some trouble with swallowing. On physical exam, signs of hyperreflexia, spasticity, fasciculations, and muscle atrophy are present in an asymmetric fashion. Tongue fasciculations are also present. No sensory loss is noted. The patient does not report any abnormality with his bowel or bladder function. What will most likely be found on muscle biopsy?

A muscle biopsy of this patient is likely to show signs of denervation, muscle fiber atrophy, and increased fibrosis. The patient's symptoms of muscle weakness, hyperreflexia, spasticity, fasciculations, and muscle atrophy in an asymmetric fashion, along with the presence of fasciculations in the tongue, are consistent with a disorder of the upper motor neuron, such as Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) or a spinal cord disorder.

In ALS, the upper motor neurons that control the voluntary muscles are affected, leading to muscle weakness, spasticity, hyperreflexia, and fasciculations. The muscle biopsy in this case would show evidence of denervation, which is the loss of nerve innervation to the muscle fibers, and muscle fiber atrophy. Additionally, the biopsy would show increased fibrosis (scarring) in the muscle tissue as a result of the denervation. This biopsy result would be consistent with a diagnosis of ALS.

It's worth noting that the patient's clinical presentation is not specific to ALS and other conditions such as spinal cord tumors, multiple sclerosis, or motor neuron disease can present with similar symptoms. Therefore, additional tests such as an MRI of the spine, EMG and nerve conduction studies, and a genetic test for SOD1 gene mutation may be needed to confirm the diagnosis.
